t: Job 21
Job’s Discourse on the Wicked
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Listen*pn carefully to my speech, And*ld let this be your consolation.
Bear*ld with me that I may speak, And*ld after I have spoken, keep mocking.
“As*ln for me, is*i my complaint against man? And*ld if it*i were,*i why should I not be impatient?
Look*ld at me and be astonished; Put*ld your*i hand over your*i mouth.
Even*ld when I remember I am terrified, And*ld trembling takes hold of my flesh.
Why*ld do the wicked live and*i become old, Yes,*ld become mighty in power?
Their*ld descendants are established with them in their sight, And*ld their offspring before their eyes.
Their*ld houses are*i safe from fear, Neither*ld is*i the rod of God upon them.
Their*ld bull breeds without failure; Their*ld cow calves without miscarriage.
They*ld send forth their little ones like a flock, And*ld their children dance.
They*ld sing to the tambourine and harp, And*ld rejoice to the sound of the flute.
They*ld spend their days in wealth, And*ld in a moment go down to the grave.
Yet*ld they say to God, ‘Depart from us, For*ld we do not desire the knowledge of Your ways.
Who*ld is*i the Almighty, that we should serve Him? And*ld what profit do we have if we pray to Him?’
Indeed*ld their prosperity is*i not in their hand; The*ld counsel of the wicked is far from me.
“How*ln often is the lamp of the wicked put out? How*ild often*i does their destruction come upon them, The*ld sorrows God*i distributes in His anger?
They*ld are like straw before the wind, And*ld like chaff that a storm carries away.
They*ild say,*i ‘God lays up one’s iniquity for his children’; Let*ld Him recompense him, that he may know it.*i
Let*ld his eyes see his destruction, And*ld let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
For*ld what does he care about his household after him, When*ld the number of his months is cut in half?
“Can*ln anyone*i teach God knowledge, Since*ld He judges those on high?
One*ld dies in his full strength, Being*ld wholly at ease and secure;
His*ld pails are full of milk, And*ld the marrow of his bones is moist.
Another*ld man dies in the bitterness of his soul, Never*ld having eaten with pleasure.
They*ld lie down alike in the dust, And*ld worms cover them.
“Look,*ln I know your thoughts, And*ld the schemes with*i which*i you would wrong me.
For*ld you say, ‘Where*ld is*i the house of the prince? And*ld where is*i the tent, The*ld dwelling place of the wicked?’
Have*ld you not asked those who travel the road? And*ld do you not know their signs?
For*ld the wicked are reserved for the day of doom; They*ld shall be brought out on the day of wrath.
Who*ld condemns his way to his face? And*ld who repays him for*i what*i he has done?
Yet*ld he shall be brought to the grave, And*ld a vigil kept over the tomb.
The*ld clods of the valley shall be sweet to him; Everyone*ld shall follow him, As*ld countless have*i gone*i before him.
How*ld then can you comfort me with empty words, Since*ld falsehood remains in your answers?”
